Posts.Content: May 21, 2009 08:14PM shelley482 wrote: There really isn't anything you can do to stabilize the platelets.  The major action of platelets is to adhere to the tissue lining to plug up a hole (it could be a cut in the skin or a blood vessel).  Most oncologists don't do preventive (prophylatic) transfusions until the platelet count gets below 20,000.  Normal ranges are dependent upon the type of technology & the equipment used to do the testing, but the 20,000 count is a pretty standard trigger for transfusion in an oncology patient who is not bleeding, not planning on undergoing an invasive procedure or doesn't have other risk factors.  Some oncologists will transfuse at a slightly higher count and some will wait until the count gets a little bit lower; there are a lot of factors that have to be considered other than just the count.
